title: Does philosophy use the scientific method? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s the other way around. The scientific method is a philosophy, specifically it’s an epistemological framework solidified by Francis Bacon. Up until Bacon, philosophers were using Aristotle’s logic to discover new truths, and they came up with some fascinating things, but in the natural world it only goes so far. With logic you have a syllogism: Premise: P implies QPremise: It is the case that PConclusion: Therefore it is the case that Q. Aristotle taught us to begin with experience, and then make logical deductions. If the conclusion follows naturally from the premises, you’ve found truth. Bacon wrote the Novum Organum, the new logic. Not only must we begin with experience, but we must also verify the conclusion with our experience as well, by making predictions of how it can be found elsewhere. Bacon’s slight refinement of Aristotle, combined with John Locke’s promotion of this line of thinking, is what caused science to take off like a thunderbolt. Other branches of philosophy don’t use the method as a matter of course (they can only use logic on non-material topics), but they might turn to science to establish the truth of a premise. So for example, a philosopher of religion might claim that hard agnosticism is a contradiction, claiming to not be able to know anything about proposition P is itself a knowledge claim about proposition P and there’s no real way to experientially verify that but the logic checks out; whereas an environmental ethicist might inquire to the findings of the environmental impact on a diminishing bee population to form a premise and conclusion on the use of some pesticide that kills bees.

Philosophy tries to go deeply into the workings of the human mind that make Science possible in the first place. So no, Philosophy does not really use the scientific method; Science uses a method which was devised by Philosophy. From Francis Bacon, or some feel, Aristotle on down. And by the way, the scientific method is not built on perfectly solid logical and epistemological foundations. Science only gives us models and laws - scientific truths, in other words - that seem to be working pretty well for the time being. Relativity theory, for example, cut the legs out from under Newtonian mechanics. RT did not show Newton’s theories to be false; it only showed them to be low-level approximations of a real universe that is far more complex than Newton ever imagined. And beautiful. And stunning in its grace and subtlety.

I think philosophy use scientific method. The study of scientific method is the attempt to discern the activities by which that victory is achieve.Surely no scientist or philosopher that is familiar with philosophy of science would claim that a scientist follows a method of science:(1) collect observations, (2) a theory is induced from observations, and (3) theory is supported by further confirming observations. Philosophy as a whole is not constrained to the scientific method. A lot of the history of philosophy concerns a search for a method of attaining truth, and while a lot of contemporary philosophers might endorse the scientific method in some specific way, the arguments/evidence that they deploy to defend this view are not scientific.

Science uses philosophy. You can do philosophy without doing science, but there are some areas of inquiry that use the scientific method to answer philosophical questions, e.g. by doing brain scans while asking people ethical dilemmas. Philosophy uses formal logic and language analysis to evaluate assertions about various matters it thinks of as “big issues”; it has evaluated how to best do this when applied to the understanding of the natural world. In the 1600s scientists were often themselves philosophers so they could consult their own minds when coming up with thinking and acting procedures that would best advance human knowledge of the natural world. Bacon first advanced a set of intelligible concepts that collectively constitute the scientific method. It includes using logic, so philosophy and science as a practice overlap with its use.

NO, IT IS THE OTHER WAY AROUND: Science and all the methods of science are indeed a subset of the philosophy of “How we know.” (Epistemology) The other main branches of philosophy are, “what we know” and “how we think.” (Though there are more refined ways of putting it.) Philosophy does use the methods of logic, evidence, and cause and effect, which indeed should be part of any thoughtful endeavor (except theology). The God stuff does not conform to any logic, evidence or causality, but it’s “truth” is given only by authority and your belief in that authority. That is why theology is NOT a valid form of philosophy.

The scientific method is a product of philosophy. The art of using critical discussions, logical arguments, and intelligent analysis to answer questions constitutes the practice of philosophical thinking, which endeavors to incite progress of thought and acquirement of greater knowledge on various subjects. The unjust nature of slavery and the unfair discrimination of not allowing women the right to vote, are examples of some of the ideas that are the products of philosophical thought. These conclusions are determined by reasoning and logic- in other words, by philosophy. The scientific method as we traditionally know it, relies on the use of “measurable” or “empirical” data to prove/disprove a hypothesis. You cannot measurably prove that slavery is unjust. It is reasoned through logic and thought ( employment of philosophy). Most advances in different fields of study, such as the development of the scientific method, resulted from philosophical thought- thoughts on whether or not knowledge can be obtained through one universal method of organized inquiry. The scientific method was born from philosophy.

You can use philosophy to do empiricism perhaps. But lots of philosophy includes data plus inference. And you are infering to the best inference based on the data. You don’t have 100% certainty in these cases or much of life for that matter. How would one use the scientific method to do political philosophy or ethical philosophy like the US Constitution is the right thing to do? Or we should defend the values of the US Constitution? Those are ethical questions that require ethical answers. Science answers “is” questions, not “ought” questions. The former are descriptive (what will be the results?) and prescriptive (what ought we do in the case of Y?)
